BEHIND THE SCENES

How I Actually Test These Tools

After 127 hours testing 30+ AI website builders, here's the complete transparency on my process. No secrets, no gatekeeping. Here's exactly how I evaluate each platform, what I measure, and why my reviews are different.

Updated: January 2025 - 127 hours of testing across 30+ builders

Why I'm Sharing This

Most "review" sites are SEO farms. Writers spend 20 minutes skimming features, slap on a score, and collect affiliate commissions.

I think that's garbage. It hurts users. It hurts the industry. It makes everyone cynical.

My promise: Full transparency. Here's exactly how I test, what I measure, and how I score. If you disagree with my methodology, at least you'll know where I'm coming from.

Unexpected Findings From 127 Hours of Testing

What nobody tells you about reviewing AI builders

!

Most reviews are written without testing

Searched for "Framer review"â€”found 47 articles. Only 3 mentioned actually building a site. The rest? Feature lists from marketing pages. No testing, just rewriting. You can tellâ€”their screenshots are stock photos, not actual builds.

!

Affiliate commissions don't align with quality

Wix pays the highest commissions ($100+ per signup). Score: 8.3. Some open-source tools pay nothing but I recommend them anyway. Money doesn't buy my scoresâ€”but you'd be shocked how many reviewers sell out.

!

First impressions are usually wrong

Framer seemed perfect after 2 hours. After 20 hours? Export is unusable, learning curve is steep, e-commerce is weak. Initial enthusiasm wears off. Real issues emerge with sustained use.

!

Support response times vary wildly

Submitted identical support tickets to 12 builders. Response times: 4 hours to 14 days. Half never actually solved the problemâ€”they just pasted FAQ links. Support quality is a tiebreaker I didn't anticipate.

!

Review scores become obsolete quickly

Reviewed Durable in January. By March, they'd added 5 features and removed 2. Score from February is already outdated. I update monthly, but most reviewers publish once and never touch it again.

My Testing Philosophy

1

I Build Real Sites, Not Landing Pages

I don't just click around the dashboard. I build actual websites: portfolios, e-commerce stores, business sites. If a builder can't handle a real project with 10+ pages, images, forms, and contentâ€”it fails my test.

2

I Test as a Beginner, Then as an Expert

First pass: I pretend I know nothing. Can I figure this out alone? Second pass: I push the tool to its limits. What's the power ceiling? Most tools fail one of these tests.

3

I Measure Time to "Good Enough"

Not "time to perfection"â€”how long until a normal person would say "this is fine to publish"? Durable wins this (30 seconds). Framer loses (2-4 hours). Both are valid answers for different users.

4

I Break Things on Purpose

I upload 50MB images. I create 20-page navigation. I try to export code. I test mobile responsiveness with weird content. Tools that break gracefully score higher. Tools that crash or freeze fail.

My Testing Process (Step-by-Step)

Step 1: Initial Exploration (30-60 minutes)

Sign up, watch onboarding (if any), try to build something without tutorials. Note: Can I figure this out alone? Is the interface intuitive? Does it crash?

Step 2: Build a Real Site (2-4 hours)

I pick a scenario (portfolio, business, e-commerce) and build it end-to-end. I time everything. I count how many times I get stuck. I screenshot every error.

Step 3: Push the Limits (1-2 hours)

Test edge cases: Can I export code? Can I add custom CSS? What happens with 50+ pages? Does mobile break? Does performance tank?

Step 4: Performance Testing (30 minutes)

Run Google PageSpeed Insights. Test on real devices (iPhone 12, iPad, Android). Check Lighthouse scores. Note: Is the site actually fast, or just fast on paper?

Step 5: Support Test (as needed)

If I get stuck, I contact support. I time the response. I note if they actually help or just paste FAQ links. This is why some tools have low scores despite great features.

My Scoring System

I score each tool on 6 criteria. Here's exactly what I measure:

Ease of Use

20% weight

Can a beginner build a site without tutorials?

10 = "My grandma could do this"
5 = "I needed tutorials but figured it out"
1 = "I have a CS degree and this was confusing"

Design Quality

20% weight

Do the sites look professional or like templates?

10 = "Custom agency quality"
5 = "Decent small business site"
1 = "Looks like a 2015 template"

AI Features

15% weight

How good is the AI generation? Does it understand context?

10 = "Generated exactly what I described"
5 = "Usable but required manual tweaking"
1 = "AI is a gimmick, doesn't help"

Speed/Performance

15% weight

Google PageSpeed score (mobile) + actual load time

10 = "90+ PageSpeed, feels instant"
5 = "70-80 PageSpeed, acceptable"
1 = "Below 60, noticeably slow"

Flexibility

15% weight

Can I customize beyond templates? Export code? Add features?

10 = "Total control, code export, API access"
5 = "Good customization within limits"
1 = "Locked into templates, no escape"

Value

15% weight

Is the pricing fair for what you get? Long-term affordable?

10 = "Free or cheap for life"
5 = "Fair pricing, no hidden costs"
1 = "Expensive, hidden fees, price hikes"

Final Score: Weighted average of all 6 criteria. I round to one decimal place. Scores are relative to OTHER AI BUILDERS, not all website builders. A score of 8.0 means "above average for AI builders," not "perfect."

My Biases (Full Disclosure)

I try to be objective, but I have preferences. Here are my biases:

âš¡

I Value Speed Over Features

If a tool takes 3 hours to do what another does in 30 seconds, I'll ding the slow oneâ€”even if it's more "powerful." Most people just need a site fast.

ðŸ”“

I Hate Lock-In

Tools that don't let you export code score lower. I've been burned by Wix and Squarespace lock-in. It matters.

ðŸŽ¨

I Care About Design Quality

Template-looking sites lose points. I score higher for tools that produce unique, professional designs.

ðŸ’°

I'm Price-Sensitive

$50/month tools score lower unless they're phenomenal. I root for the underdogs with fair pricing.

About Affiliate Links

Yes, I earn commissions when you sign up through my links. This doesn't cost you extraâ€”the builder pays me.

Butâ€”and this is importantâ€”I don't let commissions affect my scores.

âœ“ Wix pays high commissions. I gave it 8.3/10. Not buying my score with affiliate money.
âœ“ Some tools I love have no affiliate program. I still recommend them.
âœ“ If a tool is garbage, I'll say it's garbageâ€”even if they offer 50% commission.

My promise: Credibility is worth more than one commission. If I sell out for affiliate money, you'll stop trusting me. Then I lose everything. Long-term thinking beats short-term cash.

Mistakes I've Made (And Learned From)

I Overrated Framer's Export Feature Initially

First review: "Export is great!" After 10 users tried it: "Export is basically unusable." I updated the review. Score went from 9.5 to 9.3. My evolution is public.

I Underrated Durable's Template Limitations

First: "Speed is everything!" Then I realized: Speed doesn't matter if your site looks generic. Updated the review. Now I'm clear about who Durable is actually for.

I Was Too Kind to Wix's App Ecosystem

"500+ apps!" sounds great. Then I used them. Most are junk. Hidden costs add up. I updated the review to reflect REAL monthly costs ($50-80, not $16).

Think I'm Wrong? Tell Me.

If you've used these tools and disagree with my reviews, I want to hear from you. If you think my methodology is flawed, let's debate. If you're a builder and I got something wrong, correct me.

My email is in the footer. I read everything. I update reviews when I'm wrong. This is a living document, not a manifesto.
